Chicago referencing style is a style of citation which is mostly used by the researchers for the discipline of history and other subjects of social sciences. Under this citation format, there are two options, namely Notes and Bibliography and Author –Date system. In this citation format, you need to use footnotes and endnotes.

If you choose the Author-date format, you will need to add a reference page at the end of the project. The reference list should be presented in an alphabetical order by the author’s last name. If you cannot create the reference page on your own, then you can use an online tool for the same.

There are two varieties of Chicago, which are notes and bibliography and author date system. In this citation format, students are required to use footnotes/endnotes and bibliography. There will be a superscript number after the borrowed information that you have used in the content. Make sure to use commas carefully under this referencing style.

The Chicago style is used for the subjects of social sciences whereas MLA style is used for the subjects of literature. In Chicago style of writing, there is no requirement of the title page. On the other hand, in MLA style writing, you will need to create a title page.
The Chicago citation style is mostly used by the researchers and the professors. Students studying in the field of history and social sciences are asked to use Chicago citation style.

The Vancouver referencing style was previously known as the
Recommendations for the Conduct, Reporting, Editing and Publication of Scholarly Work in Medical Journals

). It was developed in the year 1978, in Vancouver. Do you need a brief overview of this particular style of referencing? Let’s delve into the primary context of this blog, a complete guide to perfecting this style of referencing. Take some time out to read through the in-depth explanation of each of the technical elements.

While using the Vancouver referencing in text, it is imperative that you develop a thorough knowledge about the technicalities associated with it. Here’s a comprehensive guide to Vancouver in Text Referencing for you. Have a look:
Avoid the use of personal communication

: Avoid the use of personal communication as a reference. However, there can be an exception if the information you are trying to provide is rare and essential (something which is unavailable from public sources). You must consider avoiding the inclusion of personal interviews, telephonic communication, emails and class handouts in the reference list.
Keep hard copies for your records:

Even though the internet is a reliable platform in today’s world, certain websites tend to delete information or replace it. Thus, it is recommended that you keep a hard copy of the retrieved information for future reference.

You must consider placing the in-text citation numbers in your Vancouver reference work after a relevant and significant sentence. The most important part of this particular context is consistency. If you are using Vancouver in text referencing, do not break the flow and include all citations in an organized manner.

Remember, references are supposed to be numbered consecutively, maintaining the order they were previously mentioned in. You should consider placing each of the reference numbers in parenthesis throughout legends, tables and texts.

This is yet another critical aspect of Vancouver style referencing. If you are wondering how to use the format in your academic work while citing multiple authors and sources, then here’s something for you:
Dawson et al [3] found that the water body tends to dry up during the day, making it difficult for the villagers, as they have to walk a mile to find another resource.

.” Don’t you agree? From celestial events like the birth of a new star to making a mistake while solving your math homework – there is a reason behind all these things. Surely, there are things that are beyond our comprehension, but if you exclude them, there is a clear set of cause and effect of every event that takes place.

When you write a cause and effect essay, you need to identify these causes and/or effects of a particular event and draft the content accordingly. While it may sound like an easy task to deal with, it actually is not. But don't worry. This blog will help you understand the crucial aspects of cause and effect essay while suggesting how you can prepare a better one for yourself.

A cause and effect essay is a piece of content where the writer needs to make a claim regarding a cause that has a certain impact, outcome or effect which can further be traced back to the initial action. This type of essay displays how the cause leads to the effect and supports the claim with proper evidence.

You can also write a cause and effect essay by picking a certain event such as the atomic bombing in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and then identify what caused it and what were its effects. In a cause and effect essay, you need to deal with a handful of actions and reactions and try to make sense of them.
Just establish a logical explanation for how these actions and reactions fit together, and you have a decent cause and effect essay ready.

Preparing a cause and effect essay will become a lot easier if you know how to structure the essay. To make it easier for you, we have broken down the complete structure of a cause and effect essay in several segments:
Now that you have a better understanding of the structure of a cause and effect essay, you can easily learn how to write a cause and effect essay on your own.
Step 1: Pick a great cause and effect essay topic:

While working on a cause and effect essay, you should always try to choose a solid history topic for it. Or you can choose a topic that is the centre of the string of events. Experts suggest that wars are generally good topics for a cause and effect essay since they have layers of causes and effects.

Also, you can consider the topics that have a bunch of events related to them. Social movements are often considered good topics for cause and effect essays. Civil rights movements, movements for women empowerment – these are great subjects for a five paragraph long cause and effect essay.

When you have found a perfect topic for your cause and effect essay, it is wiser to start the research work as soon as possible. That way, you will be able to cover more grounds. You can refer to Wikipedia to gain a basic knowledge of the topic. However, it’s not a great source of reliable information.
You should always rely on the following sources of information for the necessary research material on the chosen topic:

Try to gather information from different reliable sources. This makes your essay look more authoritative than those based on the information from a single source. It is always recommended to ask a question about the topic and answer them on your own. The more question you ask, the better your research work will get.
Create notes while conducting the research and jot down everything that seems relevant to the topic. You can then sit with the notes and connect the dots to find the answers to your questions.
Step 3: Write as it comes to you:

Don’t wait for the research work to conclude for beginning the drafting of the essay. Start writing as you perform the research work. This practice allows you to put together the ideas and process all the information that you are finding with the research work. You don’t have to worry about the quality of the essay in the beginning.

Keep on gathering information and draft them as they come to you. Don’t panic if you discover a crucial piece of information later on. You can always go back to the beginning and revise the content. In fact, the more you revise the content, the better it gets in terms of quality.

It may seem odd to write the content first and then create the outline. However, it is actually a helpful exercise that lets you take what you already have and then organise it effectively. The initial writing is nothing but a rough draft. And the outline will help you organise it. This can be a great way to get acquainted with the subject.

The more you unwind your research work and answer the questions, you can think about how you can introduce the topic in the best way possible. You can come up with a hook and make sure that it is surprising enough to attract the interest of your readers right at the beginning of the content.

You can also start with a trivia that is related to the thesis of the essay paper.  You can use a hook to start off the outline and then go on to identify the thesis. After that, you should sketch in which direction the body should move. Outline how the supporting pieces of evidence prove your thesis.

Now, create the outline for the conclusion and describe briefly how your essay proves your point. This complete outline can guide the whole process as a road map. So, you can go back to the content and make changes in the rough draft. This can also help you prepare more refined content.
Step 5: Write another draft by following the latest outline:
If the rough draft work seems to work, you should make the necessary tuning and present your essay. However, it is recommended to go back to the draft after composing the content and conduct proper
of the content. Make sure the content is appropriate, consistent, and error-free. Make sure the transition words are placed in the right place.

Have you ever seen a lawyer presenting his case in front of the judge and the jury members in a courtroom? Well, writing a persuasive essay follows a similar process. This kind of essay requires the student to pick a side on a particular topic. The student will have to present a solid argument to justify his/her stance on the topic and to alter the perception of the readers regarding the same.

The question that we are trying to focus on here is how to write a persuasive essay? While preparing a persuasive essay, the writer has to be able to persuade the readers to open up to a certain insight or perspective. You will have to pay attention proper and adequate research, have a general understanding of the readers’ preferences, and a strong idea on the issue from both positive and negative side.
A great persuasive essay always seeks to not only why the writer’s ideas are acceptable, but also why the opposing ideas or theories are inaccurate.
Now let's proceed to discuss this type of essay should be written through a step by step guide.

You must decide on a topic that comes with contradictory opinions, with multiple perspectives on the issue if possible. However, to make the process of writing this kind of essay a lot easier, you must choose a topic that’s closer to your heart or something that feel strongly about. Also, you must see to it that your topic is focused.

For instance, "Is the data breach controversy of Facebook going to discourage the users from posting on the platform?" is an ideal option for those who are looking for something that’s not too broad. You must understand that, if your take on an issue can be easily summed up to a simple “no/yes”, then, you will have nothing to talk about.

Once you have a great topic at hand, now you have to do justice to it. For that, you need to focus on a specific perspective and make the reader accept its validity as compared to any other established perspective.

For instance, if your topic is “should the internet be censored?” you have to determine whether it’s right to take away the easy accessibility of internet for any individual or the need for imposing regulations to curb the malpractices on the cyberspace.
See to it that you can defend your stance properly. In case you don’t get any solid evidence against the counter arguments on your chosen topic, you should probably consider changing the topic.

When you are pondering over how to write a persuasive essay, you give the readers a fair chance to relate to what you’re trying to convey. Now, rarely do people apply logic while arguing about a complex issue in real life, which means that tugging at their emotions while presenting your ideas is great way to alter their perceptions. What we are trying to suggest here is, while you must put your arguments together logically, but it will also be useful to present the write-up in a way that stirs the feelings of the readers.

Which side of the argument your readers are likely to support? According to your assumptions, will they agree or disagree with your ideas or theories, or will they be indecisive or reluctant. You have to be equipped with these details to understand how impactful your evidence should be to convince the audience.

Search for concrete evidence that consolidates your position. It might be facts, rational arguments, or quotes from experts. Often, incorporating your own observations and personal experience can be beneficial.
When preparing a persuasive essay, your aim should be to present them with solid evidence. You need to anticipate the counter-arguments they are most likely to present and think of them in advance.

Put your evidences together in a convincing way when you are concerned about how to write a persuasive essay. This can be done by keeping the strongest arguments in the end, to divest your reader of any doubts.
, create a detailed outline first. Now preparing a persuasive essay outline is similar to what you put together for any other essay.

While creating the outline, keep in mind that the paragraphs you include should correspond with your major arguments. What’s more, you can also add a possible counterargument in between any of the paragraph, to make your rationale more impactful and convincing.

Since the introduction is the first thing your readers will notice, it has to be impactful. In this case, you can start the section with a hook, a sentence that will help you to hold the attention of the reader. You can start with a quote here, or throw in some relevant stats or trivia. Your hook is the very first sentence that can help you convince your audience. As long as it gets your readers intrigued, you know you have successfully followed one vital rule of how to write a persuasive essay.

Every paragraph you write as the ‘body’ of your persuasive essay should be steadfastly focused on a particular stance you take. Always remember to use references and facts to back all of your claims. Understand this rule of thumb, every time you present a statement, you have to provide adequate evidence to go with it. Always ensure your evidence strengthens your arguments for your readers.

Once you have crafted the introduction and main text of the persuasive essay, it’s time to wrap it all up with fitting conclusion. Now this is where many students tend to show ignorance. Normally ending your persuasive essay would require you to rehash your thesis statement or sum up your primary arguments. Your final sentence should make the reader look forward to what comes after that. A simple suggestion, a call for action, or just an open question might point them to more detailed information, when you are trying to figure out how to write a persuasive essay conclusion.

Once you are done writing the persuasive essay paper, you need to also pay attention to the possible mistakes and inconsistencies that may persist in the document. So proofread the paper and remove any sign of error before finally submitting the paper to your university.

An annotated bibliography refers to a list of citations to information sources, such as books, articles, journals, etc. Each citation in the bibliography is followed by a brief descriptive and evaluative paragraph, which is referred to as annotation. This annotation helps inform the readers about the relevance, accuracy and quality of the source cited.
#2. Does an annotated bibliography need a title?

You can give the annotated bibliography a title that refers to a common topic all the sources share. However, you do not need to label the section “Annotated Bibliography” since the structure of the page makes it quite evident for the readers to identify it as an annotated bibliography.
#3. Is an annotated bibliography an essay?
No. An annotated bibliography is a list of references that can be used as a part of an essay. But the bibliography itself is not an essay.
#4. Does an annotated bibliography need an introduction?
The introduction to an annotated bibliography is generally short in length (not more than a couple of paragraphs). The purpose of the introduction is to identify the topic that is being researched.

#6. How long should an annotated bibliography be?

The average entry in an annotated bibliography consists of roughly around 150 words. While the annotations can be as short as one sentence each, the work’s citation information is followed by a brief paragraph which takes three to six sentences per entry.
#7. How many sources should an annotated bibliography have?

It is recommended to compile an annotated bibliography with 15 to 20 entries while drafting a research project. Each entry in the bibliography must contain a citation and a brief summary of the cited material.

A problem-solution essay follows the generic five-paragraph format in most cases:

IV. Find out the possible solution and support them with proper evidence
V. Conclude the essay by evaluating the points discussed

IV. Conclude the essay by assessing the points mentioned in the content.

is certainly no child’s play. There are so many vital aspects to meet, and points to remember. From accumulating sufficient research findings to adding relevant references to the paper, you can’t afford to miss out any of these essentials. Drafting a research paper flawlessly is mostly about proving a point with rationally explained ideas. However, you need to know about the genre of the research paper you’ll be working on. While an argumentative research paper will ask you to present two sides of a controversial issue in one paper, a definition paper is more self-explanatory. Unless you are aware of the technicalities and essential components that are associated with different research papers, ensuring flawlessness might be an issue.
Take out some time to read through this informative blog and discover the various types of research papers your professors might ask you to work on such as:

Composing a research paper involves critical thinking, a reflection of your own thoughts based on analysis and evidence collected from various sources. However, each research paper has its own conventions. Students need to follow these regulations and include all necessary elements in their work in order to shape the paper in accordance with the genre. Here are the five most crucial types of research papers you should pay heed to. Take note.

An analytical research paper is primarily about analysing different points of view associated with a particular subject matter. The perspectives in an analytical paper are supposed to be represented from a factual standpoint, rather than an opinionated one. The smart chart attached below talks about the components of an

Students must consider investing enough time in reading through the works of other researchers. However, it does not mean that the individual will only end up beating around the bush. An aspiring researcher should never talk about a similar slant, which has been explored and talked about.
One must write to analyse. Posted in

, you cannot start analysing a topic without having a concrete idea of the overall meaning and effect of the subject matter. You are basically required to take note of these three essential components.

You need to analyse the context of the assigned topic at first. This will help you to develop a primary idea regarding the background of your subject matter. Secondly, you need to be quite careful about the audience you’re trying to target. This will further assist you to frame the paper accordingly, with reader-friendly and relevant texts added to the paper. Lastly, determining the purpose of writing an analytical research paper is important. It will allow you to frame the paper with a rational tone. Once the purpose of composing the paper is clear to the audience, they will eventually develop an interest to read through the work attentively.

The primary purpose of composing an argumentative research paper is to talk about the two sides of a controversial topic in one paper. The idea is to present both sides of the issue with well-established arguments, incorporate factual details and extract evidence to derive research findings. Here’s a smart chart representing the crucial components of a well-knit argumentative paper.

The nature of research and analysis associated with an argumentative paper should be unbiased. As mentioned in the smart chart above, an argumentative paper must come up with the pros and cons of each argument. Being biased or emotional will not help you in this matter. Secondly, you must present facts that are logical in nature.
How To Write An Argumentative Essay Like A Pro

For example, if you are talking about the “pros and cons of globalisation,” you cannot afford to claim things right away. Each of the statements you try to establish must contain information from researchers and highlight both sides of the issue. And yes; it has to be unbiased or neutral in nature. Talking about in-text citation, make sure that you are seeking references from reliable sources. Unless the references drawn are relevant and factual, in-text citation won’t serve the purpose.

journal defines cause and effect research paper as an analytical work that examines the “reasons for” and the “outcomes” of a particular situation. A well-written cause and effect research paper must answer the following questions.

Compare and contrast research papers are often assigned to the students pursuing literature courses. The primary purpose of this paper is to compare two different authors or stories from a particular genre. In addition, compare and contrast research papers are used in social science to compare two different theoretical perspectives. Moreover, such papers are used in subjects like Philosophy and Business Studies as well.
How To Write A Philosophy Essay – Give Your Writing To New Heights
Before we continue to talk about the various aspects of compare and contrast papers, here’s a quick glance at the crucial components associated with the research work.

The introduction and thesis of a compare and contrast research paper must include the primary point of discussion. You must explain to your audience the subject matter you will be comparing and contrasting. In addition, talk about the purpose of the comparison and contrast as well.

Moving on to the next section, consider coming up with key similarities associated with the subject matter. You need to use explanative details and relevant examples to illustrate and support your points.

Once you are done with the comparison section, it’s time to justify the contrast section with relevant details. The contrast section should serve the purpose of explaining the key differences between the two major items of discussion in the paper. Remember, you must provide sufficient examples, so that the readers can follow and understand the logic you are trying to establish.

The conclusion should be a brief summary of all the key areas of comparison and contrast you have discussed so far. Apart from coming up with a brief recap, you need to explain the significance of the differences and similarities drawn.

If at all you are asked to choose a preferable option between the two at the end of the paper, establish a strong statement. The conclusion should be thought-provoking and impactful. Your readers must find helpful ideas and key points to take home.

Definition research papers are said to be self-explanatory in nature. You are supposed to describe the topic from a factual point of view. The paper should be devoid of emotion or any type of biased opinion. The primary idea is to draft a definition paper with pure factual details at par with other research paper findings. Now that you’re trying to figure out the key components of a definition research paper, here’s something for you to take note of.

Since composing a definition paper is essentially about presenting actual facts, you must invest enough time in research. The more literature and completed works you go through, the better are your chances to add relevant facts.
Don’t form an opinion out of emotion:

You should refrain from forming any opinion based on how you look at the subject matter. Even though a definition research paper will contain information extracted from various sources, adding up irrelevant details based on biased opinions won’t help.
The paper must contain valuable information:

Not only should your research paper contain relevant facts and unbiased opinions, but the work must also include something valuable for the readers. Don’t just write for the sake of writing. You must frame the paper with thought-provoking facts and details to engage your readers.
Simply take note of the suggestions mentioned above, and implement the same while drafting your next research work.

“To be persuasive, we must be believable; to be believable, we must be credible; to be credible, we must be truthful.”

Constructing the line of argument for a persuasive essay is not too far from what the renowned American broadcaster states. The truthfulness of your argument increases the credibility which in turn serves the purpose of persuasion. Tackling persuasive essays will be a walk in the park if you know about the critical nuances of the essay and follow expert tips on composing a winning essay.

Simply put, a persuasive essay is a document composed in such a way that it projects the dominance of one line of argument on another. The arguments are formed following clear, logical reasoning and analytical style with a focus on substantiating the establishment of one line of argument over the other. This form of

is also known as an argumentative essay. The two-pronged target of a persuasive essay is to both educate the reader about the subject in discussion and provide evidence for the particular argument within the topic that is chosen by the writer. Composing a persuasive essay requires a lot of in-depth research and succinct argumentative narrative along with the ability to present the arguments in a logical and comprehensive manner.

Elemental to a persuasive essay is its unique composition that follows a logical transitory path, stringing together pieces of evidence presented along the way to substantiate the vital argument in question. With compelling evidence and proper structuring of the argument, the purpose of persuading the reader that your take on the topic is the dominating one over other perspectives is of crucial essence and must follow a regimented structure. The four primary elements of a persuasive essay are the introduction, the body, the counter-argumentative stance, and the conclusion.

The introductory paragraph presents the topic to the reader, and as the saying about impressions goes, this is the part where you have to pack in as much punch as you can for your persuasive essay. Use a powerful ‘pull’ or an element that captures the attention of your reader and compels him to read further into your argument. Providing an overview of the argument, you must also include a thesis statement that clearly delineates your take on the topic. As the closing sentence of the opening paragraph, the thesis statement must contain the stance to be argued for in the persuasive essay.
Expert Tip: Try including quotes, surprising statistics or relevant amusing anecdotes for an engaging opening paragraph for your persuasive essay.

The body paragraphs are your real playground, and you get to construct them in accordance with the arguments that are to be presented for substantiating your claims about the chosen stance. It is important to remember that the body paragraphs should each contain one logical reasoning for your argument and evidence to support it in the form of statistics, facts and external references. The body of the essay should ideally be about three paragraphs long with all the facts supporting your claim laid out logically and coherently, together forming an argumentative stance with clarity. Place the supporting details for your argument within each paragraph in the body of the essay logically and create linking sentences that ensure smooth transition between the paragraphs.

Expert Tip: Compose the linking sentences as opening lines for each body paragraph at first. This way, you can ensure a smooth transition from one piece of evidence that supports your argument and the next one.

The opposing paragraph, placed between the body of the essay and the conclusion, is for presenting all the counter-arguments to your argument and refuting them logically along with supporting evidence. Showing all the opposing arguments in one paragraph, you will need to be at your argumentative best for this one. You must, at first, understand the opposing views to your stance and create a logical structure in your mind about how to refute those arguments using your argumentative skills as well as supporting evidence that justify your claims. In case there are too many views that oppose your stance, choose the most compelling one(s) and construct your opposing paragraph around that. The purpose of this paragraph is to present the counter-arguments in a way that they are in contrast to your point of view and show the reader through your presentation of the argument why they can be refuted and the reason that yours has an extra edge over them.

Expert Tip: The most logically accepted way to go about refuting an argument is to present contrasting evidence that helps you to find inconsistencies or loopholes that leave place for further explanation within the opposing views.

In conclusion, you persuasive essay summarizes your argument by restating it along with some of the central points of your logical perspective. You must not introduce new lines of argument in the concluding paragraph as its purpose is to review and summarize the entire essay in a few sentences along with a closing sentence that strikes a chord with your readers. You will need to go over your entire essay and identify the central points that must be mentioned in the concluding paragraph while summarising the essay. Your concluding paragraph must also state the thesis question containing your stance on the issue along with the important lines of argument that support the stance. Apart from the concise and accurate summary, your concluding paragraph must contain a call to action in the closing sentence. In the closing line, you must encourage the reader to delve deep into the topic through further study or present a situation that demands prompt action.

Expert Tip: The closing sentence should either encourage the reader to study further about the topic, predict an outcome that requires immediate action, or recommend them some ideas that they can put into use in line with your perspective about the argument.

“I would rather be attacked than unnoticed. For the worst thing you can do to an author is to be silent as to his works.”

An abundance of the much-celebrated authors agree, not unlike the legendary English author, that literature stands firm on the grounds of literary analyses and critique from the readers. All those college and university essays on literary analyses of poems, prose, novels, and whatnot are actually for instilling in the students the skills of composing a deft critique by understanding the author's reasons behind the choice of words and phrases. Why do the writers write the way they do? They do so simply to invoke the feelings in us that they wish to – with the help of the words and sentences that they string together, they are able to bring life to situations, inanimate objects and create a world of dilemmas among the minds of the readers.

Understanding the writer’s perspective starts with understanding the conscious choice that goes behind every word that he pens down. For that, we must be aware of the tools and techniques that are at his disposal and the ones that he frequently falls back on to bind us in a spell of words, phrases and sentences through his creations.

Simply put, literary terms are names given to the various techniques, tools and devices that the writers use in their works to produce a targeted feeling, sensation, or special effects in the narration - especially used while composing a critique or analyses of literature. The literary devices, tools and techniques in the writer's quiver all have specific literary terms assigned to them, so they are easy to identify and explain when writing analyses or critique of the literature.

Literary terms are the ones that help us categorise the type of literary device that has been used by the writer while explaining a certain scenario or character in the narrative. These terms help us learn more about the writer’s perspective as well as provide us with insights about his unique writing style.
Must-know literary terms for writing impressive essays

Writers have myriad methods of expressing their ideas and feelings through their works. However, understanding the perspective of the writer, imperative while composing a literary analysis, may prove to be difficult at times. To make things easier for you, here are the must-know literary terms, compiled from the (almost) unending list of tools and techniques used by the writers, that will help you to nail that literary essay and impress your professors.

A constant favorite among authors, wordplay through the use of literary devices has evolved through the classics and still find their place in the literature of the new age. One classic literary device that has been used in myriad instances is alliteration. Analysing classics and poems will now be easy with following definition and examples collected from classic literature, compiled at one place so you can compose a literary essay like a pro.

A literary device that repeats a speech sound in consecutive words (or those in proximity) within a sentence is called alliteration. Used to give stress to a syllable, alliterations usually occur at the beginning of the words, normally with the help of a consonant. Alliterations lend flow, structure and style to the literary work, be it poem or prose. Here are some examples of alliteration used in literature throughout time that gives an idea of the timeless literary device that it is.
The usage of contrast and comparison for

the writers to convey a message through their works more efficiently. That is perhaps the reason for literature containing so many different literary techniques for contrasting and comparing. From analogy to symbolism, comparisons have formed a solid foundation for literature through the ages. The next time you compose a literary essay, look out for signs of the usage of literary techniques of comparison in the form of allegories, analogies, similes, metaphors or symbolism, and are prepared to tackle the literary analyses impressively.

The use of analogy is vast and extensive in literature through the ages. An analogy is the comparison drawn between two ideas or things that are apparently dissimilar but helps the reader to grasp the writer's point of view quite easily with an explanation or a twist in it that tells all. Analogies help the readers grasp complex and abstract ideas in relation to everyday things, quite often mundane and routinely. The following are some of the examples of analogy as observed in literature.
Here, Longfellow draws an analogy between the gushing of his poems and the gushing of tears from the eye or rains from the summer clouds.
Here, the inseparable, as well as needful nature of the relationship between a cup and a saucer has been used as an analogy to explain the relationship between memory and love.

Allegory is a literary device that has found its place in the works of many renowned authors throughout the ages. An allegory uses the narrative entwining the plot and characters to depict a larger and more abstract idea, value or moral than the one it apparently represents. In allegory, there are two layers of meaning as authors use this literary device to add a multi-layered dimension to their writings. The literary term for depicting an abstract value or idea – usually having a political or religious significance – through the usage of characters, plots, and events in the narrative is thus called allegory. Here are some examples of the usage of allegory in classic literature and iconic cinemas that help you understand the nature and purpose of this much-favoured literary device.

A form of analogy, similes are used to compare between two objects, people or places in a narrative to show the similarities using the words such as ‘like’ or ‘as’. Authors prefer to use a simile when they want to say that object 01 is similar to or ‘like’ object 02. The usage of similes, found in everyday usage of English, is also another favourite literary device for the authors who wish to draw resemblances in their narratives. A literary device used for comparison, here are some examples of similes from literature.

A metaphor is a powerful literary device used for drawing a form of analogy of similarity between two things. Do not confuse a metaphor with a simile for the former uses a direct comparison by stating that the two things are akin whereas the latter shows the similarities as being alike. In a metaphor, the author uses a compelling comparison to say that object 01 is object 02 and not merely ‘like’ it in nature. The function of a metaphor is drawing the readers’ attention to the detailed description in the narrative as well as appeal sharply to their senses to captivate them.

One of the more popular literary devices, symbolism finds its place in literature through the ages. We use symbolism in our daily conversations quite often and some even draw inspirations from literature loaded with symbolic significance. Symbolism occurs when a writer assigns a value or idea to an object (symbol) that is not similar to the value or idea it literally represents. Everyday objects and colours represent the symbols for various ideas or values such as a red rose represents romance, and the colour white depicts purity and tranquillity universally. The following are some of the examples of symbolism from literature and movies.

Bringing life to words that spring forth pictures and emotions in the minds of the readers is perhaps one of the best things about being a writer. As the authors have immense power to wield with their pens, their descriptions have brought forth a wide array of literary terms to categorise the ways the writers describe the characters, attributes, places and events in their narratives. The following are the most important forms of descriptive literary terms that are used widely in literature by hundreds of authors.

Imagery is a literary device that serves the purpose of description by appealing to the readers’ five senses. Invoking feelings and sensation through the usage of words in one or more than one of the five senses is the main function of imagery. Children’s literature has traditionally depended heavily upon imagery to bring life to a scene that needed detailed description. The following are some of the examples from literature that will help you understand more about the usage of imagery.

A favorite among the quirkiest of authors, hyperbole is the art of deftly using exaggeration to convey a depiction or description to the reader with emphasis. A literary device that is fun to use, hyperbole is, simply put, an exaggerated description of the actual occurrence, attribute or event. The function of a hyperbole is thus to either introduce an element of amusement or to emphasise something with the usage of exaggerated terms and words. Some of the famous examples of the usage of hyperbole are as follows.

Another fun-filled literary device, personification assigns humanly traits to inanimate or non-human characters so that the attributes or behaviour of the characters can be better explained in the narrative. When the authors decide to assign a human attribute to a non-human entity in their works, they use personification for bringing inanimate things to life, to add to the vividness of the description, and for perceiving the world through human eyes. The following are the examples of how some noted authors have used personification in their literary works.

Literature is based firmly on the foundations of tried and tested methods of narration and storytelling. Some literary elements have found their way into timeless literature of all kinds and have an all-pervasive impact among all the languages of the world. The literary elements that are easily found in almost all narratives in literature are archetype and allusion.

Archetypes are essentially typecasting of innate human nature and dichotomies that have existed since time immemorial. The authors have been using archetypes through the characters and theme of the narrative since a long time. Archetypes exist in movies, songs, plays, stories and even poems. They represent the timeless dichotomies and some of the innate traits of humans that have stood the test of time and are here to stay. Here are some of the examples of archetypes in literature and cinema.

Every author has a bunch of storytelling secrets up their sleeves. The most important of the literary devices that help in storytelling are conflict and theme. While the former highlights the struggle that propels the narrative forward, the latter conveys an underlying message on which the story or narrative is spun.

Conflict is the literary device that helps authors to show the struggles of the protagonist or the hero archetype by introducing problems, challenges and dilemma that the hero ultimately conquers to emerge as the champion (or not, in case of tragedies). The conflict can be either external, where the hero battles against enemies that are outside (such as an opponent in a game or archenemies hunched for battle) or internal, where the hero has to tame the demons inside in order to be able to emerge victoriously. The five types of conflict in literature are Man vs. Man, Man vs. Society, Man vs. Self, Man vs. Nature, and Man vs. Technology. The following are some of the examples of conflict in literature and cinema.

The theme of a literary work is the underlying message that it wishes to convey. It is an indispensable literary element found in all forms of literature, and authors always resort to conveying a message through the theme. The theme has a personalised touch from the author; it not be confused with the topic of the literary work in analysis. The following are some of the examples of theme that will help you gauge its usage in literature through the ages.

Now that you know about the important literary terms do not hesitate to compose that stellar literary analysis essay due over the weekend. A thorough knowledge of these literary terms will now help you to easily identify the patterns in the literary works of the stalwarts as well as help you gain an understanding of the reason behind they chose the words or phrases that they did. Literary devices are the greatest weapons that the authors have, and you should know about them to write an in-depth literary analysis or just to appreciate literature better.

Comparative essay, as the name suggests is widely based on differences and similarities between certain notions, declarations, theories and judgments. Comparative essay, comparison essay or compare and contrast essays are all the same, and based on the fundamentals of significant differences and points of contrast that one has to look for, study, research, analyze and establish.

Now here are the 10 most effective and recommended tips on how to write a comparative essay. Following the helpful advice mentioned below will help you come up with impressive comparative essays, displaying a structured composition from every possible angle.

For every comparative essay, recognizing the theme of investigation and the primary idea that you would represent and establish in the paper is crucial. So, first things first; you have to be sure of what value your comparative essay will add to the readers and whether the theme of discussion is legit enough to carry out.

For instance, if you need to compare two different eras of literature then pick a stance which is relevant and comparable, e.g. the literary psychoanalysis or the literary style prevalent during those periods. Based on a particular subject matter, choose to go ahead with the paper.
Mere recognizing the theme of the comparative essay isn’t enough if you lack the required materials and informative details in support of the claims or the statement you’re trying to establish.

If you have guidelines provided by your professors then follow the same, then you may consider visiting online libraries, extract information from reliable archives and read enough books for self-knowledge. That would make your comparative essay more insightful.
Also to be added, you should consider reading previous works on the theme or the subject matter. This would help you to draw inspirations and develop ideas on how to write a comparative essay.

If you are confused how to write a comparative essay and make it look attractive, then take note of the fact that a wide and crystallized overview is what your audience expects to see in the paper. So, you cannot disappoint them by loosely covering the aspects with no explanative columns included in your comparative essay. Try this instead; here’s an example:
Negligible or little faith in nature
Plots were usually complicated and lengthy in nature
Usage of modern and pragmatic expressions

There’s no denying that a comparative essay without a thesis statement can prove to be a misguiding one in the long run. It is one of the primary sections where you are supposed to talk about your ideas, main theme and the results identified through the comparisons. Here is a brief idea about how to write a comparative essay using a perfect thesis statement.

Although the eras of Romanticism and Victorianism have an equally crucial role to play when it comes to literature and literary studies, there are certain remarkable differences if we are to talk about idealism, plot and language.

There are two basic methods of comparison that can be incorporated in your comparative essay, namely the block method and the point-by-point method. If you are proposing or introducing something new to your readers a theory in contrast to something conventional, then opting for the block method can help you in this matter.

If in case you choose to show comparisons directly and make your comparative essay an impactful one with a well-knit write-up, then following the point-by-point method will allow you to produce essays with a helpful explanation of all crucial points that you may wish to establish and highlight.

This is yet another vital point of concern. It is supposed to be considered and remembered when it comes to composing a comparative essay or any other composition for the matter of fact. It can be of MLA style, APA format or the Chicago Style and many more. Whenever you are using any research findings and data in the paper, make sure to cite the source in the appropriate format. Skipping this crucial part and missing out on citing the used sources can put your composition in trouble in the long run. So, you need to be quite careful in such cases.

Prior to your commencement of the comparative essay writing task, it is absolutely important for you to strategize and prepare an accurate outline for the essay. You can use attractive bullet points to jot down your plans and represent them in a constructive way in the form of a structured column.

An essay outline is a nice way to represent your contents that one would find within the paper. As far as impressing your professors is concerned, there’s no substitute for a constructively outlined comparative essay.

Begin with the body paragraphs at first. This is where you will be using the majority of the accumulated data and every other detail in order to compare and contrast the main context of your comparative essay topic. Once you are done with the major chunk of the task, move next to the concluding portion of your paper. It would be much easier for you compose the conclusion based on the story you have developed in the body paragraph of your comparative essay.

Now that you’re done with the body and the conclusion, start with the introduction, which is basically a combination of rephrased and reorganized write-ups based on what you have included in the body and in the conclusion. This, as a result, will also help you to maintain a fine balance between the three-most vital sections in the paper.
It is to be remembered that plagiarism is a big NO-NO when it comes to composing comparative essays or any other academic project.

One can even have his/her essay rejected if the composition gets subjected to plagiarism. So, you need to be quite careful in this matter and refrain from using plagiarized content, irrespective of the fact whether you are committing an intentional or accidental plagiarism.

All your effort, accumulation of data, adding references and citing crucial sources in your comparative essay paper will simply go down the drain if you end up submitting a loosely revised copy, filled with numerous contextual flaws, grammatical errors, editing flaws and proofreading mistakes. So, make sure you’re revising your comparative essay thoroughly before submission.

So, this was all about composing perfect comparative essays. Make it a point to keep each of the suggestions mentioned above in mind and never miss a chance to steal the show with stellar comparative essay compositions.

Essay writing is possibly the most common form of assessment that a student has to work on throughout their academic career, be it in the high school or while pursuing a university degree. There are multiple reasons why essay writing is encouraged by every educational institution across the world. The prime reason for assigning students with various essays is to assess their ability to grasp a particular topic and to enhance the student’s knowledge regarding the subject. Such write-ups allow the professors to evaluate the skills and proficiency of the students. So simply put, an essay is a kind of assignment that meticulously describes and emphasizes on a topic. Typically, an essay is written to elaborate on your opinions, ideas and views regarding a specific topic. The objective of an academic essay assignment is to influence the students to enhance concepts and ideas through their writing. Since the process of essay writing comes with multiple aspects, the student can get the opportunity to hone their skills on reading, analyzing, conducting research and maintaining brevity, exposition and precision of the document.

Speaking of essays, there are multiple categories of them and students have to be acquainted with all of these variants at some point in their academic pursuits. Essays being the most popular types of academic assignments, you will be required to prepare diverse types of such papers during the span of your academic sessions. Naturally, majority of the students may not be as skilled in dealing with the complex process of essay writing. But it is crucial for the students to get acquainted with the different kinds of academic essays since that will allow them to handle any complicated paper with ease. So, for the convenience of the students, here’s a comprehensive list of the distinct types of essays that they should know about.

A narrative essay is elaborated through a personal story. So naturally this kind of an essay would focus on the personal experiences of an individual, a narrative essay offers the scope for the writers to be acknowledged directly and to present themselves in a better way. Narrative essays tend to be more personal, empirical and subjective. This area of

allows the students to have clarity of their thoughts and ideas and also lets them translate those ideas on the paper in an artistic way. Many people often believe that writing a narrative essay would be a fairly simple, but that’s not the case. While writing this type of essay, it is essential to provide a convincing personal experience through the write-up so that the readers can be interested in the piece as well.

Argumentative essays are also commonly known as Persuasive Essays. The objective of writing a persuasive essay is to convince a reader about a certain concept or theory, normally something that you believe in. While presenting this type of essay papers, the writer has to maintain a justified and logical stance to prove that their concept is more relevant and rational than the other prevailing arguments and theories. When composing a persuasive essay paper, the principal objective of the writer is to inspire a reader to consider a certain notion presented by you or to compel them to read further into the arguments that you’ve provided. Persuasive essays require an extensive amount of research, and a detailed knowledge of every angle of the subject you are elucidating, to develop the awareness of the readers regarding that topic or subject.

The expository essay needs to be informative in its approach. In these kinds of essays, the writer attempts to present a topic or subject to the readers through the application of facts and figures. This type of academic paper delves into producing an objective evaluation of a specific topic. While preparing this type of essay, the writer offers sufficient details and elaborates on a topic by including various relevant statistics, facts, and evidence. Always remember that expository essays are primarily based on facts, and there is no scope for expressing your personal opinions or views on the paper. That’s why the students should conduct precise research on a specific concept, analyze facts, structure the essay according to the concept, and produce an argument associated with that concept in a legible and concise way.

To put it in a simple manner, a compare and contrast essay elaborates on the distinctions and similarities between two individuals, places, incidents or things. The primary function of this type of essay is to elucidate how some situations or thoughts are distinct from or similar to one another. While approaching this variant of academic essay, it is mandatory for the students to establish an association between ideas or texts, and also indulge in a critical evaluation of those ideas. Preparing a compare and contrast essay not only requires the writer to present elaborate descriptions of the ideas and theories, but they should also be able to put together an intriguing analysis on why the idea tends to be similar or contradictory.

Descriptive essays are one of the most popular among all the prominent essay types. While preparing this type of essay, a student has to elucidate on a particular person, object, experience, place, situation, emotion etc. It allows you with an opportunity to explain a certain experience. This type of essay paper lets you harness your creative prowess for creating a compelling piece of write-up. Writers mostly make use of this type of academic essay to influence an opinion on a particular object. The role of a descriptive essay is to explain the meaning of a certain subject or a specific field under discussion. It is crucial for the writers to proceed with their discussion after conducting a thorough evaluation.

Cause and effect essay is another distinct type of essay that students are likely to come across during their academic years. Writing this kind of essay is like painting a picture in which one incident or situation gives rise to certain reactions. The writer needs to have a cohesive idea of a particular incident or situation and the reason behind such an occurrence. So, when you proceed with writing a cause and effect essay, you should highlight the thoughts and ideas effectively regarding an incident and also elucidate on the consequences of that specific incident. This type of academic essays is an ideal way of organizing and offering your thoughts and perceptions in an academic setting.

This is another extremely significant variant of essays that students need to be aware of, to get admission in a reputed educational institution. It typically consists of a statement of purpose or a personal statement. It is a piece of writing prepared by a student with the aim to apply for graduate or postgraduate programs in a reputed university or college. These days, the college or university application essay is an essential part of the university and college admission process. That’s why it’s necessary for the students to be accustomed to preparing such write-ups. When presenting an application essay, a candidate should describe about his/her life, academic achievements, experiences, other noteworthy skills that they possess and also the reason to apply to a particular college or university and their ambitions.

Normally, it is said that a case study is a comprehensive assessment of a person, community or an event. A case study essay is considered to be a crucial paper in any prominent academic discipline and it is necessary for the students to be efficient with their case studies to succeed in their academic endeavours. The purpose of a case study essay is to provide with a more detailed and authentic assessment of an event or a situation. While preparing this type of essay, you are required to offer authentic and precise information of the condition that the essay is focusing on. A case study is a rational piece of write-up which evidently comprises of thorough research and proficient application of concepts, theories and views.

The objective of Scholarship Essays is that it enables the scholarship committee of an institution to gain some insights about you and your dedication to achieve your goals. Presenting a brilliantly written essay can aid you to accumulate more funds to pay for your college education. However, you need to remember that scholarship essays are basically written to offer the scholarship provider with an understanding and insight into the person writing the application and allow them to peak into your academic and general background. Scholarship Essays are a kind of personal essay and the primary criterion of this type of write-up is to persuade the scholarship committee that you are in every way eligible for it.

Analytical or analysis essay is again a rather usual form of academic write-up that students, especially the ones pursuing higher studies, are used to preparing. In simple words, an analytical essay means that a student must produce some sort of claim or argument in connection with something that they’re evaluating in the paper. While presenting this kind of write-up, you should emphasize on thoroughly analyzing another relevant piece of work associated with your topic. You may also find that similar ideas and issues have already been discussed by other people. And that makes it convenient for you to research the specific topic and compile the ideas efficiently.

A Five-Paragraph essay, as the name indicates, is a variant that comprises of five paragraphs. Five-paragraph essays should possess an appropriate introductory section, three paragraphs consisting of the main content and a fitting conclusion. Owing to the particular structure of the essay, it is also recognized as one-three-one essay or a three-tier essay. In the introductory section, you have to explain the primary theme of the entire essay and have to include the thesis statement possibly in the first paragraph to make it interesting. The main text should echo the thesis statement, and you must provide adequate evidence to establish your arguments in the main text of the paper. The conclusion should reinstate the thesis and wind up the essay topic.

Term paper essays hold immense significance in a student’s academic career as they are required to present these academic papers as per the requirements of their respective institutions. Term paper is an elaborate piece of writing on a certain subject taken from the curriculum that a student follows during school or college term. It’s almost similar to a research paper that is produced by students during the span of an academic term. The primary objective of preparing term paper essays is to highlight an idea or an event or discuss about a specific point. So typically it stresses on an in-depth discussion about the topic.

Definition essay is another category that students have to be acquainted with during their academic pursuits. Definition essay is ideally a brief piece of write-up dedicated to a particular subject. To prepare this type of essay, the student will need to define a statement that could mean different things and is arguable. Students can write definition essays in a simple manner if they pick a less rigid or mechanical topic that can be elaborated by offering your understanding or experience, and without resorting to any complexities. It emphasizes on a personal yet academic definition of certain term or phrase. However, it is essential that you select a phrase or term that will offer you enough materials to discuss about.

Critical essay is also one prominent variant of essays that the students are assigned with during their tenure at college and university. Ideally, this paper provides an elaborate critical insight of a piece of work, whether that’s a film, book, story, article, poem or painting. The students are generally given broad topics to work when they present a critical analysis. The function of critical essay is to prepare an analysis of some significant aspect of a piece of work. So this type of an essay aims to evaluate both the strong and the weak points and the specific methods of someone else’s creation.

Deductive essays are an essential type of assignment in assessing the knowledge level of students belonging to various academic discipline. This type of essay employs deductive reasoning which is based on the theory that given as a set of clues or circumstances, one can make a viable assumption regarding a situation. To put it simply, an individual can solve an issue or detect a person if provided with sufficient information. Particularly, deductive reasoning is known to consider individual aspects, measures them against the prevailing knowledge about the concerned topic and combines them up to arrive at a conclusion.

While writing a classification essay, the students will ideally have to compile things into separate categories and provide appropriate examples that are suitable for every category. To present such an essay, students have to go through the following steps;
Before proceeding with the writing part, it is crucial to select the classification criteria.

An exploratory essay is a brief piece of a write-up in which the writer proceeds through an issue or assesses an experience or idea, without actually trying to support a statement or a thesis. Exploratory essay varies from most other kinds of
as the name of the essay itself suggests that you move through unknown areas and should find your way in the course of the essay.

The primary reason why an informal essay is different from other kinds is because of its flexibility and informal style. The readers must be provided with a conversational style of writing when they are reading this type of essay. One of the most crucial things is to maintain the element of your personality. The reader should decipher your philosophy and your vision easily. Contrary to their formal counterparts, informal essays were written for pleasure.

A personal essay is an elaborative type of assignment that often involves a myriad of writing styles. Most personal essay requires the writers to discuss a particular individual, incident or phase in their life. The idea is to describe the incident or situation in a manner that the reader can comprehend and identify. This type of academic papers typically consists of descriptive writing.
The process essay is a type of academic assignment through which a writer elaborates a step-by-step method of how something is accomplished. Process essays can be categorized into two forms:

An informative process is normally presented from the third person perspective, while a directive process essay is usually produced in the second person point of view. In both these categories, the steps are ideally structured in order in which the steps are carried out.

A response essay varies from the formal review ideally in the aspect that it is presented in the first person. As opposed to more formal write-ups, the application of the first person can be adopted in a response essay. In this type of paper, you will still have to prepare a formal evaluation of the piece of work you're analyzing (this could be a book, a work of art, or a film), but you also have the liberty to put forward your impressions and perceptions to the paper.
Now all those students who frequently have difficulty distinguishing between these types of essays can get an idea about each one of them.

At all levels of education, especially in school, students are often assigned to give a

speech. Writing a persuasive a speech can be quite a challenging task for many of you, as you need to put across your point and justify it adequately to convince your audience. However, what is harder is choosing a good persuasive speech topic.

Basically, a persuasive speech contains relevant evidence and a clear explanation to prove a point. It is therefore quite essential to put in a lot of thought before choosing one of the good persuasive topics for your persuasive speech.

When written correctly on good persuasive topics, your persuasive speech can win accolades from the audience and thus help you win the hearts of people. If you are still unsure about how to start a persuasive speech, then we can help you. Here are seven quick tips that will help you draft an excellent persuasive speech.

Do not be vague about the side you choose. Make it clear whether you support the issue or against it. Hence, the audience understands the point that you are trying to make with your speech. Put across your arguments with explicit statements and specific claims. Back your arguments with enough evidence so that the listeners understand the importance of the issue.

Make sure that you choose a topic that you believe and support personally. The issue must have a personal meaning so that it is more convincing and compelling. When you select a subject matter that is relevant and interesting, you automatically become passionate while researching it. Personal attachment helps you convey your thoughts and ideas to the audience better.

A persuasive speech demands extensive research to make sure that you provide facts and information that is accurate or well-founded. Research thoroughly so that you understand which facts to use and which ones to omit. Use your school library for scholarly journals and articles from valid data. Educate yourself about your persuasive speech topic in general because it is only after you know the matter thoroughly that you will be able to take a clear stand.

Before you put your arguments on the table, organise all your pieces of evidence in a proper structure. Create separate paragraphs to address the different reasons and provide evidence proving them correct under each point. Go through persuasive speech examples and see how they start. You can also listen to speeches given by eminent personalities to understand how to address your audience appropriately.

, it becomes very important to know and understand the audience who you will have to face. Every human being is dynamic and therefore behaves in different ways. So before you start drafting your persuasive speech, make sure you adjust the tone and the vocabulary of your speech accordingly.

You need to remember that your audience is gullible and moldable. So stick to your side and support the cause fiercely. Do not just give your opinion on a matter. Back it up with meaningful evidence so that your audience knows why you are supporting your position. While working on the persuasive speech, remember to include the possible refutations for the topic and prove why the comebacks are wrong. This will make your speech more compelling.

Make sure your speech reflects integrity. Every persuasive speech is bound to have an element of controversy. So be honest in your writing to mellow down the bias in your writing. While taking a stand, do not be overly against the other side of the coin and do not disregard it entirely.

is a common question that occurs very often in the minds of the students. Writing this

is completely different from other essays. Here, you will take a position on the given topic and give logical reasons to back it up. So, you must learn how to do it in the right way. In this blog, you will get some useful tips on how to write a philosophy essay which will make the whole writing process easier for you.

You will be providing a reasoned defence of the claim you are making. It cannot be based on your personal or any other philosopher’s opinions. You must give logical and solid justifications or reasons to the readers to agree or accept your claim. In your philosophy paper, you will start by creating your thesis, and after this, you might have to do one or more than that from the below-mentioned points:

Whatever be the purpose of your essay, you must give clear reasons for the thesis you are making. You should never consider that you don’t need to present arguments because you already know that the thesis is true. It is your readers who need to believe, and for that, you will have to clear it out for them.
Your philosophy essay will have a logical argument, but you must ensure that you make it unambiguous and to the point, and provide sound reasons to support it. It must not be poorly explained.

, you have to present your original thinking, your own critical explanation, and your own argument to support or criticise the argument. This will show that you know what you’re talking about and have critical thinking skills.

Here we are going to describe the process of crafting a beautiful philosophy essay along with examples. So you can develop a proper idea how to impress your supervisor when assigned a philosophy essay.

From the beginning, you must get to the point straight. You must keep it concise, and write in a way to guide the readers about what they will find in the essay. Present the topic of the essay, its structure, the importance of the topic and the thesis in the introductory paragraph. Don’t forget to define any special term used in the thesis.
- For an essay whose topic is ‘Human’s ability to tell whether he/she is dreaming or not according to Descartes’, the introduction part can be like the following:

“Since the appearance of ‘The Meditations’ by Descartes in the 1600s, it has become a principal discussion in Philosophy that whether it is possible for one to know if he/she is dreaming. This question was fuelled by the compelling logic provided by Descartes. According to him, since we can be tricked by our senses, it cannot be said with a guarantee that we are capable of seeing the reality. Hence, in conclusion, Descartes has said throughout the first two Meditations that certainty can be given to the presence of a being called ‘I’, which is nothing but a mind.”

You should determine how many arguments or points you will provide to establish your thesis. You can start each paragraph with a topic sentence representing one idea in support of your thesis statement. Explain the concepts, prospects, and opinions that can back up the thesis. Following this, present your personal arguments in favour of your claims in the thesis. A good way to strongly establish your argument is to present the counter arguments and views that oppose your position and assess them. Remember that you can’t just claim that an opposing view is wrong; you have to show why they are wrong. Make sure that each idea will lead the readers to believe in your position.
: A small example of the body paragraph can be as following:

“According to Descartes, it is our intellect, which is responsible for the senses or awareness. So, he was only certain about the presence of a mind. However, this gives rise to the questions of how one can know that he/she is awake. If he or she knows, how that person can be certain that this perception of being awake is not a dream itself.

The awareness of our experiences does not let us decide if we are having dreams or awake. So the question remains the same both in being awake and dreaming. So, we cannot differentiate between dreaming and being awake. An example illustrated by Descartes is, “How often, asleep at night, am I convinced of just such familiar events- that I am here in my dressing-gown, sitting by the fire- when in fact I am lying undressed in bed!” If it is to be believed that there is no difference between a person’s awareness while dreaming and the awareness at the time of being awake.

In the closing paragraph, you must repeat your thesis and present your arguments in a summary. You can also write about any limitations related to your claim or thesis. However, the conclusion is not a place to introduce new points, which you did not discuss in the essay.
Make sure that in the essay, one paragraph continues to the other in a flow and for that, you can use transitional phrases.
The conclusion can be as following:

“It is not possible to prove that a person’s sensational experiences are not illusory. The implication of successfully refuting this would bring a big problem in the real world. It is not possible to turn face from the real issues of the real world by considering it to be a deception by the senses. This way, it won’t be possible to react and take actions for critical problems of the practical world.”

If you want to produce a good philosophy essay, you will have to show your mastery of this discipline. You can’t do that just by reiterating the relevant philosophical arguments, ideas, and views. You have to analyse them and critically explain them to the readers utilising your own examples, words, and description of the philosophical concept.
So, if you remember the above mentioned points and utilise them in your philosophy essay, you will easily develop a thoughtful and impressive paper.
